title: Elaine Bonazzi
text:
Elaine Bonazzi (August 28, 1929 – January 29, 2019) was an American <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="mezzo-soprano">mezzo-soprano</a> who had an active international career from the 1950s through the 1990s. A singer with an unusually broad repertoire that encompassed both classical and contemporary works, she notably created roles in the world premieres of operas by composers <a href="Dominick%20Argento">Dominick Argento</a>, <a href="David%20Carlson">David Carlson</a>, <a href="Carlisle%20Floyd">Carlisle Floyd</a>, <a href="Gian%20Carlo%20Menotti">Gian Carlo Menotti</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Pasatieri">Thomas Pasatieri</a>, and <a href="Ned%20Rorem">Ned Rorem</a>. In the United States she was particularly active with the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a>, the <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Opera">Santa Fe Opera</a>, and the <a href="Washington%20National%20Opera">Washington National Opera</a>.
Life and career.
Born in <a href="Endicott%2C%20New%20York">Endicott, New York</a> in 1929, Bonazzi earned a Bachelor of Music in vocal performance from the <a href="Eastman%20School%20of%20Music">Eastman School of Music</a> in 1951. She then pursued graduate music studies at <a href="Hunter%20College">Hunter College</a> and the <a href="Juilliard%20School">Juilliard School</a>, and studied privately with Elda Ercole in New York City. In 1955 she was the contralto soloist in <a href="Johann%20Sebastian%20Bach">Johann Sebastian Bach</a>'s "<a href="Mass%20in%20B%20minor">Mass in B minor</a>" with the <a href="Oratorio%20Society%20of%20New%20York">Oratorio Society of New York</a> at <a href="Hunter%20College">Hunter College Auditorium</a>. In 1956 she portrayed Lady Pamela in <a href="Daniel%20Auber">Daniel Auber</a>'s "<a href="Fra%20Diavolo%20%28opera%29">Fra Diavolo</a>" with the Hunter College Opera. That same year she portrayed <a href="Gertrude%20Stein">Gertrude Stein</a> in the lauded <a href="Off-Broadway">Off-Broadway</a> production of <a href="Virgil%20Thomson">Virgil Thomson</a>'s "<a href="The%20Mother%20of%20Us%20All">The Mother of Us All</a>" at the <a href="Phoenix%20Theatre%20%28New%20York%29">Phoenix Theatre</a>.
In 1958 Bonazzi made her debut with the <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Opera">Santa Fe Opera</a> as Meg Page in "<a href="Falstaff%20%28opera%29">Falstaff</a>". That same year she portrayed Mrs. Linton in the world premiere of <a href="Carlisle%20Floyd">Carlisle Floyd</a>'s "<a href="Wuthering%20Heights%20%281958%20opera%29">Wuthering Heights</a>". She returned frequently to the SFO during her career, portraying such roles as Baba the Turk in "<a href="The%20Rake%27s%20Progress">The Rake's Progress</a>", Countess Geschwitz in "<a href="Lulu%20%28opera%29">Lulu</a>", Herodias in "<a href="Salome%20%28opera%29">Salome</a>", La chatte in "<a href="L%27enfant%20et%20les%20sortil%C3%A8ges">L'enfant et les sortilèges</a>", Marcellina in "<a href="The%20Marriage%20of%20Figaro">The Marriage of Figaro</a>", <a href="Mark%20Smeaton">Mark Smeaton</a> in <a href="Gaetano%20Donizetti">Gaetano Donizetti</a>'s "<a href="Anna%20Bolena">Anna Bolena</a>", The Mother in "<a href="Mavra">Mavra</a>", the old woman in "<a href="Yerma%20%28opera%29">Yerma</a>", Prince Orlofsky in "<a href="Die%20Fledermaus">Die Fledermaus</a>", Saint Catherine in "<a href="Jeanne%20d%27Arc%20au%20b%C3%BBcher">Jeanne d'Arc au bûcher</a>", Tisbe in "<a href="La%20Cenerentola">La Cenerentola</a>", Zita in "<a href="Gianni%20Schicchi">Gianni Schicchi</a>", and the title roles in "<a href="Carmen">Carmen</a>" and "<a href="Regina%20%28opera%29">Regina</a>". Her final appearance at the SFO was as Mrs. Peachum in <a href="John%20Gay">John Gay</a>'s "<a href="The%20Beggar%27s%20Opera">The Beggar's Opera</a>" in 1992.
In 1960 Bonazzi made her debut with the <a href="Washington%20National%20Opera">Washington National Opera</a> as the Countess in <a href="Pyotr%20Ilyich%20Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a>'s "<a href="The%20Queen%20of%20Spades%20%28opera%29">The Queen of Spades</a>". She returned to Washington D.C. later that year to perform the role of Death in <a href="Igor%20Stravinsky">Igor Stravinsky</a>'s "<a href="The%20Nightingale%20%28opera%29">The Nightingale</a>" under the baton of the composer. Other roles she performed with the WNO during her career included Agata in "<a href="Maria%20Golovin">Maria Golovin</a>", The Old Baroness in <a href="Samuel%20Barber">Samuel Barber</a>'s "<a href="Vanessa%20%28opera%29">Vanessa</a>" Seibel in "<a href="Faust%20%28opera%29">Faust</a>", and Ursule in "<a href="B%C3%A9atrice%20et%20B%C3%A9n%C3%A9dict">Béatrice et Bénédict</a>". In 1986 she appeared at the WNO as Queen Isabella of Spain in "Christopher Columbus", a <a href="pastiche">pastiche</a> of music by <a href="Jacques%20Offenbach">Jacques Offenbach</a> patched together by Patric Schmid. Her final appearance with the company was as the Countess in "The Queen of Spades" in 1989.
In 1965 Bonazzi created the role of Christine in the world premiere of <a href="Ned%20Rorem">Ned Rorem</a>'s "<a href="Miss%20Julie%20%28Rorem%20opera%29">Miss Julie</a>" for her debut with the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a>. She sang several more roles with the NYCO, including Clairon in "<a href="Capriccio%20%28opera%29">Capriccio</a>", Frau von Luber in "<a href="Der%20Silbersee">Der Silbersee</a>", Katisha in "<a href="The%20Mikado">The Mikado</a>", Mme. Armfeldt in "<a href="A%20Little%20Night%20Music">A Little Night Music</a>", Mother in "<a href="Louise%20%28opera%29">Louise</a>", Mrs. Lovett in "", and Suzuki in "<a href="Madama%20Butterfly">Madama Butterfly</a>". In 1979 she created the role of Grace-Helen Broome in the world premiere of <a href="Dominick%20Argento">Dominick Argento</a>'s "<a href="Miss%20Havisham%27s%20Fire">Miss Havisham's Fire</a>" with the NYCO. Her final appearance with the NYCO was as Marie in <a href="Frank%20Loesser">Frank Loesser</a>'s "<a href="The%20Most%20Happy%20Fella">The Most Happy Fella</a>" in 1991 with director <a href="Arthur%20Allan%20Seidelman">Arthur Allan Seidelman</a>.
In 1962 Bonazzi made her debut at the <a href="Opera%20Company%20of%20Boston">Opera Company of Boston</a> as Maddalena in "<a href="Rigoletto">Rigoletto</a>" under conductor <a href="Sarah%20Caldwell">Sarah Caldwell</a>. In 1963 she created the role of The Spy in <a href="Gian%20Carlo%20Menotti">Gian Carlo Menotti</a>'s "<a href="Labyrinth%20%28opera%29">Labyrinth</a>" which was commissioned for television by the <a href="NBC%20Opera%20Theatre">NBC Opera Theatre</a>. In 1964 she appeared as Suzuki in "<a href="Madama%20Butterfly">Madama Butterfly</a>" at the <a href="Dallas%20Opera">Dallas Opera</a>. In 1966 she was one of the soloists in the world premiere of Stravinsky's "Requiem Canticles" at the <a href="McCarter%20Theater">McCarter Theater</a> in Princeton.
In 1971 Bonazzi portrayed the Sorceress to <a href="Maureen%20Forrester">Maureen Forrester</a>'s Dido in "<a href="Dido%20and%20Aeneas">Dido and Aeneas</a>" at the <a href="Caramoor%20International%20Music%20Festival">Caramoor International Music Festival</a>. She returned to Caramoor the following year to portray Arnalta in "<a href="L%27incoronazione%20di%20Poppea">L'incoronazione di Poppea</a>" under the baton of <a href="Julius%20Rudel">Julius Rudel</a>. In 1972 she created the title role in the world premiere of <a href="Thomas%20Pasatieri">Thomas Pasatieri</a>'s <a href="Emmy%20Award">Emmy Award</a> winning opera, "<a href="The%20Trial%20of%20Mary%20Lincoln">The Trial of Mary Lincoln</a>" which was commissioned by the <a href="National%20Educational%20Television">National Educational Television</a> network under the leadership of <a href="Peter%20Herman%20Adler">Peter Herman Adler</a>.
In 1973 Bonazzi portrayed Daniel in the <a href="Handel%20Society%20of%20New%20York">Handel Society of New York</a>'s production of "<a href="Belshazzar%20%28Handel%29">Belshazzar</a>" under conductor <a href="Stephen%20Simon">Stephen Simon</a> at <a href="Carnegie%20Hall">Carnegie Hall</a>. That same year she gave her only performance with the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a> in New York as the Sorceress in "Dido and Aeneas" under the baton of <a href="Richard%20Dufallo">Richard Dufallo</a>. In 1976 she created the role of Lavinia Davenport in the world premiere of Thomas Pasatieri's "<a href="Washington%20Square%20%28opera%29">Washington Square</a>" at the <a href="Michigan%20Opera%20Theater">Michigan Opera Theater</a>.
Bonazzi appeared in numerous rarely seen operas with the <a href="Clarion%20Music%20Society">Clarion Music Society</a> at <a href="Alice%20Tully%20Hall">Alice Tully Hall</a> during the 1970s and 1980s, including Anfione in <a href="Agostino%20Steffani">Agostino Steffani</a>'s "<a href="Niobe%2C%20regina%20di%20Tebe">Niobe, regina di Tebe</a>", Apollo in <a href="Francesco%20Cavalli">Francesco Cavalli</a>'s "<a href="Giasone">Giasone</a>", Baroness Aspasia in <a href="Gioachino%20Rossini">Gioachino Rossini</a>'s "<a href="La%20pietra%20del%20paragone">La pietra del paragone</a>", Juno in Gluck's "<a href="Le%20nozze%20d%27Ercole%20e%20d%27Ebe">Le nozze d'Ercole e d'Ebe</a>", and Lavinia in Steffani's "Amor vien dal destino".
In 1981 Bonazzi portrayed The Marquise of Birkenfeld in "<a href="La%20fille%20du%20r%C3%A9giment">La fille du régiment</a>" with <a href="Tulsa%20Opera">Tulsa Opera</a>. In 1983 she portrayed Matryona Pavlovna/Korablyova in <a href="Franco%20Alfano">Franco Alfano</a>'s "<a href="Risurrezione">Risurrezione</a>" at the <a href="Cincinnati%20Opera">Cincinnati Opera</a>. In 1985 she portrayed Baba the Turk at the <a href="Sarasota%20Opera">Sarasota Opera</a>. That same year she created the role of Madame d'Urfé in the world premiere of Argento's "<a href="Casanova%27s%20Homecoming">Casanova's Homecoming</a>" at the <a href="Minnesota%20Opera">Minnesota Opera</a>. In 1993 she created the role of Lady Neville in the world premiere of <a href="David%20Carlson">David Carlson</a>'s "The Midnight Angel" at the <a href="Opera%20Theater%20of%20Saint%20Louis">Opera Theater of Saint Louis</a>. She returned to Saint Louis the following year to perform the role of Mistress Quickly in "<a href="Falstaff%20%28opera%29">Falstaff</a>".
On the international stage Bonazzi performed leading roles at the <a href="Dutch%20National%20Opera">Dutch National Opera</a>, the <a href="National%20Theatre%20in%20Belgrade">National Theatre in Belgrade</a>, and the <a href="Palacio%20de%20Bellas%20Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a> in Mexico City. In 1964 she portrayed The Secretary in "<a href="The%20Consul">The Consul</a>" at the <a href="Vancouver%20Opera">Vancouver Opera</a>. In 1974 she portrayed Countess Geschwitz in <a href="Alban%20Berg">Alban Berg</a>'s "<a href="Lulu%20%28opera%29">Lulu</a>" at the <a href="Festival%20dei%20Due%20Mondi">Festival dei Due Mondi</a>.
Bonazzi taught for many years on the voice faculty at the <a href="Stony%20Brook%20University">Stony Brook University</a>, retiring from there in 2012. Prior to teaching at SBU, she was a member of the vocal music faculty at the <a href="Peabody%20Institute%20of%20Music">Peabody Institute of Music</a>. Several of her students have had successful singing careers, including soprano <a href="Christine%20Goerke">Christine Goerke</a> and mezzo-soprano <a href="Deanne%20Meek">Deanne Meek</a>. She was married to cellist Jerome Carrington.
Bonazzi died in 2019 in <a href="Elizaville%2C%20New%20York">Elizaville, New York</a>, aged 89.
